subject: Determine security group API dynamically
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-09-23 05:00:29.000000000', 'files': ['openstack_dashboard/test/api_tests/neutron_tests.py', 'openstack_dashboard/test/api_tests/network_tests.py', 'openstack_dashboard/api/neutron.py', 'openstack_dashboard/dashboards/project/instances/tests.py', 'openstack_dashboard/dashboards/project/instances/tables.py', 'openstack_dashboard/api/network.py', 'openstack_dashboard/local/local_settings.py.example', 'openstack_dashboard/test/test_data/neutron_data.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/horizon/commit/6f1307e47212550c7b9f7fc6bb050ef5ae525f3e', 'message': "Determine security group API dynamically

This commit removes enable_security_group from local_settings.py
and determines which security group API should be used (nova or
neutron).

Closes-Bug: #1227804

As described in bug 1203413, there is a case where Nova security group
with Neutron driver causes a problem. The type of 'name' attribute in
add_security_group_to_instance and remove_security_group_from_instance
depends on the backend, integer for nova security group driver and
UUID for quantum security group driver to make it work as expected.

enable_security_group config parameter produces a situation where
Nova security group with Neutron driver. We can avoid this situation
by removing this parameter when using Horizon.

Change-Id: I713c6ad166e142929f0a708e93a8fedb0de48640
"}]
commit_message:
Determine security group API dynamically

This commit removes enable_security_group from local_settings.py
and determines which security group API should be used (nova or
neutron).

Closes-Bug: #1227804

As described in bug 1203413, there is a case where Nova security group
with Neutron driver causes a problem. The type of 'name' attribute in
add_security_group_to_instance and remove_security_group_from_instance
depends on the backend, integer for nova security group driver and
UUID for quantum security group driver to make it work as expected.

enable_security_group config parameter produces a situation where
Nova security group with Neutron driver. We can avoid this situation
by removing this parameter when using Horizon.

Change-Id: I713c6ad166e142929f0a708e93a8fedb0de48640

commit_message:
Remove colon in item names in LBaaS detail page

Also changes the followings for consistency with other pages:
- Replace "Tenant ID" with "Project ID"
- Show '-' when name or description is empty
- Apply yesno filter for True/False field
- Rearrange field order in pool and VIP details

Change-Id: I82a533cee61dee148aac8872868effd78e46cc45
Closes-Bug: #1230057

commit_message:
make _user_to_credentials() work with v2 users

The _user_to_credentials() method in policy.py expects users to be
v3-style.  Since v2 is still supported, make it stop exploding when
fed v2 users.

Fixes Bug: 1229980

Change-Id: Iddf56a48f684ce78bc69dd84fba39a3b3c1045ea

commit_message:
Pin hacking>=0.7.2,<0.8 in global-requirements

There have been several bugs reported in nova lately for flake8 errors
but they are only showing up if you run against the latest hacking
version. For those with a stale virtual environment or pip mirror, these
can sneak by due to the older version of hacking required in
global-requirements.

Closes-Bug: #1230277
Related-Bug: #1227655
Related-Bug: #1229753

Change-Id: Idf3da7d8982a08b69ae1f18e1d2565358f9ba075

commit_message:
Support glance client can get ipv6 image url correctly

This patch is for fix bug 1208784. In openstack ipv6 environment,
if the os image url is not provided, need use the provided host
to generate literal ipv6 image url.

commit_message:
Fix json version of bootable check

This is a follow up to change id:
  I8a4b1f4ce3a6a420e8152ea8c66a9b3fc127fe96

The initial change only addressed the xml aspect of the bug
and ignored the json tests.

This change updates the check to catch the same errors when
performing the json version of the checks.

Both of these patches are temporary and after the Cinder update
lands should be replaced with a proper/strictly enforced check of
'true' and 'false' values in the volume['bootable'] field.

Change-Id: Iffe5d380410f5c698018a5c3106c99af05f0b80d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/35/47935/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

Then we'll make this strict again and #specifically check "true" or "false" if val in ['true', 'True', True]: return True else: return False # NOTE(jdg): Revert back to strict true/false checking # after fix for bug #1227837 merges boot_flag = self._is_true(fetched_volume['bootable']) if 'imageRef' in kwargs: self.assertEqual(boot_flag, True) if 'imageRef' not in kwargs: self.assertEqual(boot_flag, False) # NOTE(jdg): Revert back to strict true/false checking # after fix for bug #1227837 merges boot_flag = self._is_true(updated_volume['bootable']) if 'imageRef' in kwargs: self.assertEqual(boot_flag, True) if 'imageRef' not in kwargs: self.assertEqual(boot_flag, False)
deleted_lines: if 'imageRef' in kwargs: self.assertEqual(fetched_volume['bootable'], True) if 'imageRef' not in kwargs: self.assertEqual(fetched_volume['bootable'], False) if 'imageRef' in kwargs: self.assertEqual(updated_volume['bootable'], True) if 'imageRef' not in kwargs: self.assertEqual(updated_volume['bootable'], False)

commit_message:
Update man pages

Updates the man pages based on the latest oslo.config and
Keystone code. oslo.config is version 1.2.0.

To generate the man pages, ran

 tools/with_venv.sh bin/keystone-all -h

and copied the output to the man page. A couple of changes were
required because of the output formatting.
1) Escape * in *.config otherwise it's considered emphasis without
   end.
2) --log-file is split to separate lines which results in a space
   in the output, so put it back together.

Change-Id: Ic76b7eafd04551ec01a3c117b9d5a73471b1e4ce

commit_message:
Update OpenStack services to support qpidd element

Configuration files are changed so that qpid is used as the rpc_backend
instead of kombu (rabbitmq) if it is specified in the metadata.

Add qpid-python to Heat, Neutron, and Cinder requirements.txt file.
These elements install using venv and don't use the system installed
libraries. These changes can be removed if requirements.txt is changed
upstream. There are two bugs tracking these changes:
https://bugs.launchpad.net/heat/+bug/1225191
https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1225232

Change-Id: I9bf6ab9d3bae668e592af65b5c8075a487e07261
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-image-elements refs/changes/68/43968/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Add setup-passwords script.

The script is run once from devtest and writes out a file
(tripleo-passwords by default) that you source into your shell
environment to set the password environment variables.  If you lose
your shell accidentally, you can source the file again later.

Change-Id: I6317d4d66a95e181d4b7e8893e6502cc07c62026

See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. set -e set -o pipefail SCRIPT_NAME=$(basename $0) SCRIPT_HOME=$(dirname $0) function show_options () { echo "Usage: $SCRIPT_NAME [options]" echo echo "Generate passwords for devtest and write them out to a file" echo "that can be sourced." echo echo "Options:" echo " -f, --file -- Specify path for passwords file." echo " Defaults to tripleo-passwords in the current directory." echo " -o, --overwrite -- Overwrite file if it already exists." exit $1 } TEMP=`getopt -o hof: -l help,overwrite,file: -n $SCRIPT_NAME -- "$@"` if [ $? != 0 ] ; then echo "Terminating..." >&2 ; exit 1 ; fi # Note the quotes around `$TEMP': they are essential! eval set -- "$TEMP" while true ; do case "$1" in -f | --file) FILE=$2; shift 2 ;; -o | --overwrite) OVERWRITE=--overwrite; shift 1 ;; -h) show_options 0;; --) shift ; break ;; *) echo "Error: unsupported option $1." ; exit 1 ;; esac done FILE=${FILE:-"tripleo-passwords"} OVERWRITE=${OVERWRITE:-""} # Don't overwrite $FILE if it already exists and the overwrite option was # provided. if [ -f $FILE -a -z "$OVERWRITE" ] then echo $FILE exists, not overwriting. echo Either delete the file first, or specify -o exit 1 fi cat > $FILE << EOF UNDERCLOUD_ADMIN_TOKEN=$(os-make-password) UNDERCLOUD_ADMIN_PASSWORD=$(os-make-password) UNDERCLOUD_GLANCE_PASSWORD=$(os-make-password) UNDERCLOUD_HEAT_PASSWORD=$(os-make-password) UNDERCLOUD_NEUTRON_PASSWORD=$(os-make-password) UNDERCLOUD_NOVA_PASSWORD=$(os-make-password) OVERCLOUD_ADMIN_TOKEN=$(os-make-password) OVERCLOUD_ADMIN_PASSWORD=$(os-make-password) OVERCLOUD_CINDER_PASSWORD=$(os-make-password) OVERCLOUD_GLANCE_PASSWORD=$(os-make-password) OVERCLOUD_HEAT_PASSWORD=$(os-make-password) OVERCLOUD_NEUTRON_PASSWORD=$(os-make-password) OVERCLOUD_NOVA_PASSWORD=$(os-make-password) OVERCLOUD_DEMO_PASSWORD=$(os-make-password) EOF

commit_message:
API GET to return only minimal data

Requests to list top-level resources like nodes, chassis or ports will
now return only a subset of it's attributes, a subresource called /detail
could be used to get the full details of the resource. This changes
is supposed to improve performance and UX, also, others OpenStack APIs
already do it the same way so it's also about being consistent between
other APIs.

Change-Id: Ida45febf60e44d50e506f3680ab371e1027010c4
Closes-Bug: #1227431

commit_message:
Fix port deletion in NEC Plugin

Cascade on delete from ports.id to packetfitlers.in_port is added
to ensure packet filter entries associated with a port.
Also joined query of packetfilter with port query is added
to avoid additional packetfilter query by port_id.

Fixes: bug #1212102

Change-Id: I8a67649f3361480eda6377b1d8a30bebd18aa714

commit_message:
Correct deleted_at value in notification messages

The deleted_at value in notification messages is currently
set from the terminated_at value in the instance record.

A comment in the code says this is to avoid confusion between
terminated_at and deleted_at,  but swapping the names doesn't
seem to be a great way to address that.

In practice "terminated and not deleted" is a transient state
unless an error occurs, and the time gap is very short.  But
deleted_at is always set when the entry is deleted in the DB,
whereas terminated_at can be left unset in some error cases.

Rather than present terminated_at as the deleted_at value in
the message we include both and let the recipient decide which
they want to use.

Fixes bug: 1227080

Change-Id: Ic67f66b6c64be1a8f43f4fdd5b1fac25f1414247

commit_message:
Clean up automated changes to requirements

Some of us like to reuse sandboxes, and keep them up to date.  This
is very difficult to do if devstack leaves modifications to
requirements.txt files after a run, since 'git pull' may refuse to
overwrite those changes.

This modification has devstack undo the changes to the requirements
files, to leave the sandbox in a clean state again.

Change-Id: Ia2d928ade8141b59b56a2c4548d760bf6911a3e5

commit_message:
tests: fix places check for timestamp equality

It's actually up to the microsecond, and not finer, so the default
places value of 7 isn't good enough.

Change-Id: Ic0438db4c9039a904a43547d5c5181400a84d22f
Closes-Bug: #1230099

subject: Functional test suite for devtest.
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-09-21 16:06:28.000000000', 'files': ['tests/base.py', 'tests/README.md', 'tests/test_overcloud.py', 'tests/test_seed.py', 'tests/test_undercloud.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-incubator/commit/ffdc9ac65b0cac9413a8bdfdb461140e28d411c7', 'message': "Functional test suite for devtest.

This commit adds a test suite that can be run against the OpenStack
environments that are set up by devtest.  There are tests for the
seed, undercloud, and overcloud.  The test suite could be run at the
end of a devtest run, or at various points along the process to test
progress (e.g., run tests in test_seed.py after setting up the seed).

The tests are useful to make sure that things were set up correctly
and how devtest expects.  Granted, if you get to the very end of
devtest, it's likely everything worked.  But, they also add value in
that they can be used to troubleshoot what went wrong if a devtest
step fails unexpectedly.  For example, a test that verified the nova
baremetal flavor was created as we expect, might uncover a bug if the
flavor wasn't set up correctly by Nova.

We could also have TOCI execute the tests at the end of a run.

For now, there are just a few tests to illustrate how this might work.
More tests could be added for things like:
 - verifying neutron was set up correctly
 - verifying nova was set up correctly (flavors, nodes created, etc)
 - shelling out to virsh to verify baremetal{0-2} were setup
 - basically, we could test anything that devtest does.

Change-Id: I71e0276146e5270556d1aeea457f77de31cc0c12
"}]
commit_message:
Functional test suite for devtest.

This commit adds a test suite that can be run against the OpenStack
environments that are set up by devtest.  There are tests for the
seed, undercloud, and overcloud.  The test suite could be run at the
end of a devtest run, or at various points along the process to test
progress (e.g., run tests in test_seed.py after setting up the seed).

The tests are useful to make sure that things were set up correctly
and how devtest expects.  Granted, if you get to the very end of
devtest, it's likely everything worked.  But, they also add value in
that they can be used to troubleshoot what went wrong if a devtest
step fails unexpectedly.  For example, a test that verified the nova
baremetal flavor was created as we expect, might uncover a bug if the
flavor wasn't set up correctly by Nova.

We could also have TOCI execute the tests at the end of a run.

For now, there are just a few tests to illustrate how this might work.
More tests could be added for things like:
 - verifying neutron was set up correctly
 - verifying nova was set up correctly (flavors, nodes created, etc)
 - shelling out to virsh to verify baremetal{0-2} were setup
 - basically, we could test anything that devtest does.

Change-Id: I71e0276146e5270556d1aeea457f77de31cc0c12

commit_message:
Log message for image object not found in swift

The get method of the swift driver needs logging when the image
is not found in the container.
This change also adds the location of the image to the message.

Fixes bug 1227786

Change-Id: I33bd5ee5edf985211139d9d4519b494b2b19b5a9

commit_message:
Add log_additional_locale config property for easy log translation

Just like it is possible to configure a log file by specifying the
log_file property in the {service}.conf file, allow the secondary locale
log to be configurable via a simple {service}.conf property.

This should allow setting up the secondary locale log relatively easy
without necessarily having to create and setup a logging.conf.

For example, if nova.conf has log-file = '/var/log/nova/api.log' and
log_additional_locale='zh', the following secondary log file will be
created:

    /var/log/nova/api.log
    |------------/zh
                 |--/api.log

Change-Id: I85b4645e18277f498f7b040b7acc6d91d55245ac
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo-incubator refs/changes/76/42176/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import mock @mock.patch('os.path.exists') @mock.patch('logging.handlers.WatchedFileHandler') def test_secondary_locale_log(self, MockWatchedFileHandler, mock_osexists): mock_osexists.return_value = True log_root = log.getLogger(None).logger translation_handler = None # Config without log_additional_locale should result # in no TranslationHandler, and the opposite should be true self.config(log_file='/some/path/foo-bar.log') log._setup_logging_from_conf() for h in log_root.handlers: if isinstance(h, log.TranslationHandler): translation_handler = h break self.assertIsNone(translation_handler) self.config(log_file='/some/path/foo-bar.log', log_additional_locale='es') log._setup_logging_from_conf() for h in log_root.handlers: if isinstance(h, log.TranslationHandler): translation_handler = h break self.assertIsNotNone(translation_handler)

Expand DeprecatedOpt documentation

It is not a priori obvious how deprecated options are chosen, so
expand the docstring a bit

Change-Id: If10b45fb042b4a4d6063129b693228fd6ca86b82
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.config refs/changes/81/48181/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Multi-value options will return all new and deprecated options. For single options, if the new option is present ("[blaa]/foo" above) it will override any deprecated options present. If the new option is not present and multiple deprecated options are present, the option corresponding to the first element of deprecated_opts will be chosen.

commit_message:
Rebuilding stopped instance should not set terminated_at

At the end of a rebuild action, nova checks the original vm_state
of the instance to see if it was stopped. If the instance was
originality stopped, nova will stop the newly rebuild instance.
Right before the stop, nova updates the instance and sets it's
terminated_at to utcnow(). Due to this, the periodic usage audit
does not send usage for the instance.

There's no reason for setting tereminated_at here, it should only
be set as part of instance deletion

Fixes bug: 1189554

Change-Id: I141aba1b4f3c15a4c17e1fc401ae9479acafb23f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/56/47556/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-09-12 13:33:12.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/heat/commit/da3249ef8361562f9151c09ec96f91285d4dbe1b', 'message': 'Fixed issue with resource OS::Neutron::Port creation

commit_message:
Fixed issue with resource OS::Neutron::Port creation

Heat was not able to create resource OS::Neutron::Port
when ip_address attr was not specified in fixed_ips property.

From Neutron point of view, attribute ip_address of property fixed_ips is
not required and can be ommited. But when specified it is should be valid
ip address.

Bug #1224472

Change-Id: I39ba545762b96fb7267c91afa5c36bd7d16be6a6
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/74/46274/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Note: `ip_address` attribute of `fixed_ips` property is optional # and should not be present according to Neutron specs. if 'fixed_ips' in self.props and 'ip_address' in props['fixed_ips']: if props['fixed_ips']['ip_address'] is None: del props['fixed_ips']['ip_address']

commit_message:
Add keystone backend

This patch adds keystone support for the client. It is possible to
either provide os_auth + endpoint through the CLI or all other required
params to retrieve both or one of them.

Implements blueprint keystone-integration

Change-Id: Id059d075aabb26f92c82b0a863d85743d8564f69
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-zaqarclient refs/changes/41/48041/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright (c) 2013 Red Hat, Inc. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); # you may not use this file except in compliance with the License. # You may obtain a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, # WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or # implied. # See the License for the specific language governing permissions and # limitations under the License. from oslo.config import cfg from keystoneclient.v2_0 import client as ksclient from marconiclient.auth import base from marconiclient.common import utils # NOTE(flaper87): Some of the code below # was brought to you by the very unique # work of ceilometerclient. class KeystoneAuth(base.AuthBackend): _CLI_OPTIONS = [ cfg.StrOpt("os_username", default=utils.env('OS_USERNAME'), help='Defaults to env[OS_USERNAME]'), cfg.StrOpt("os_password", default=utils.env('OS_PASSWORD'), help='Defaults to env[OS_PASSWORD]'), cfg.StrOpt("os_project_id", default=utils.env('OS_PROJECT_ID'), help='Defaults to env[OS_PROJECT_ID]'), cfg.StrOpt("os_project_name", default=utils.env('OS_PROJECT_NAME'), help='Defaults to env[OS_PROJECT_NAME]'), cfg.StrOpt("os_auth_url", default=utils.env('OS_AUTH_URL'), help='Defaults to env[OS_AUTH_URL]'), cfg.StrOpt("os_auth_token", default=utils.env('OS_AUTH_TOKEN'), help='Defaults to env[OS_AUTH_TOKEN]'), cfg.StrOpt("os_region_name", default=utils.env('OS_REGION_NAME'), help='Defaults to env[OS_REGION_NAME]'), cfg.StrOpt("os_service_type", default=utils.env('OS_SERVICE_TYPE'), help='Defaults to env[OS_SERVICE_TYPE]'), cfg.StrOpt("os_service_type", default=utils.env('OS_SERVICE_TYPE'), help='Defaults to env[OS_SERVICE_TYPE]'), cfg.StrOpt("os_endpoint_type", default=utils.env('OS_ENDPOINT_TYPE'), help='Defaults to env[OS_ENDPOINT_TYPE]'), ] def __init__(self, conf): super(KeystoneAuth, self).__init__(conf) conf.register_cli_opts(self._CLI_OPTIONS) def _get_ksclient(self, **kwargs): """Get an endpoint and auth token from Keystone. :param kwargs: keyword args containing credentials: * username: name of user * password: user's password * auth_url: endpoint to authenticate against * insecure: allow insecure SSL (no cert verification) * project_{name|id}: name or ID of project """ return ksclient.Client(username=self.conf.os_username, password=self.conf.os_password, tenant_id=self.conf.os_project_id, tenant_name=self.conf.os_project_name, auth_url=self.conf.os_auth_url, insecure=self.conf.insecure) def _get_endpoint(self, client): """Get an endpoint using the provided keystone client.""" return client.service_catalog.url_for( service_type=self.conf.service_type or 'queuing', endpoint_type=self.conf.endpoint_type or 'publicURL') def authenticate(self, api_version, request): """Get an authtenticated client, based on the credentials in the keyword args. :param api_version: the API version to use ('1' or '2') :param request: The request spec instance to modify with the auth information. """ token = self.conf.os_auth_token if not self.conf.os_auth_token or not request.endpoint: # NOTE(flaper87): Lets assume all the # required information was provided # either through env variables or CLI # params. Let keystoneclient fail otherwise. ks_kwargs = { 'username': self.conf.os_username, 'password': self.conf.os_password, 'tenant_id': self.conf.os_project_id, 'tenant_name': self.conf.os_project_name, 'auth_url': self.conf.os_auth_url, 'service_type': self.conf.os_service_type, 'endpoint_type': self.conf.os_endpoint_type, 'insecure': self.conf.insecure, } _ksclient = self._get_ksclient(**ks_kwargs) if not token: token = _ksclient.auth_token if not request.endpoint: request.endpoint = self._get_endpoint(_ksclient, **ks_kwargs) # NOTE(flaper87): Update the request spec # with the final token. request.headers['X-Auth-Token'] = token return request

subject: Authentication API + NoAuth backend
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-09-19 08:17:40.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/python-zaqarclient/commit/7cb1e5b6f38c5b6a085e572bcb1b99a284839d0e', 'message': 'Authentication API + Keystone backend

The API still needs some refactor but, the idea is to have multiple
authentication drivers that can be used depending on how Marconi was
configured.

Some things that could be change are:

    * The `authenticate` method should be request-agnostic, instead, we
      could get a target instance back from it which will then be used
      to complete the request at a transport level.

    * Avoid patching the request instance, as per above point.

Target definition is still under discussion, which is why this patch is
being submitted as-is.

Implements blueprint python-marconiclient-v1

commit_message:
Authentication API + NoAuth backend

This patch adds a auth base class with a NoAuth backend, which is the
default auth method for Marconi.

Implements blueprint keystone-integration

Change-Id: I94e2c12cf0648be8557d8b2ddc43a7aa76ae313f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-zaqarclient refs/changes/34/47334/7 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

oslo.config import cfg from keystoneclient.v2_0 import client as ksclient from marconiclient.auth import base from marconiclient.common import utils # NOTE(flaper87): Some of the code below # was brought to you by the very unique # work of ceilometerclient. class KeystoneAuth(base.AuthBackend): _CLI_OPTIONS = [ cfg.StrOpt("os_username", default=utils.env('OS_USERNAME'), help='Defaults to env[OS_USERNAME]'), cfg.StrOpt("os_password", default=utils.env('OS_PASSWORD'), help='Defaults to env[OS_PASSWORD]'), cfg.StrOpt("os_project_id", default=utils.env('OS_PROJECT_ID'), help='Defaults to env[OS_PROJECT_ID]'), cfg.StrOpt("os_project_name", default=utils.env('OS_PROJECT_NAME'), help='Defaults to env[OS_PROJECT_NAME]'), cfg.StrOpt("os_auth_url", default=utils.env('OS_AUTH_URL'), help='Defaults to env[OS_AUTH_URL]'), cfg.StrOpt("os_auth_token", default=utils.env('OS_AUTH_TOKEN'), help='Defaults to env[OS_AUTH_TOKEN]'), cfg.StrOpt("os_region_name", default=utils.env('OS_REGION_NAME'), help='Defaults to env[OS_REGION_NAME]'), cfg.StrOpt("os_service_type", default=utils.env('OS_SERVICE_TYPE'), help='Defaults to env[OS_SERVICE_TYPE]'), cfg.StrOpt("os_service_type", default=utils.env('OS_SERVICE_TYPE'), help='Defaults to env[OS_SERVICE_TYPE]'), ] def __init__(self, conf): super(KeystoneAuth, self).__init__(conf) conf.register_cli_opts(self._CLI_OPTIONS) def _get_ksclient(self, **kwargs): """Get an endpoint and auth token from Keystone. :param kwargs: keyword args containing credentials: * username: name of user * password: user's password * auth_url: endpoint to authenticate against * insecure: allow insecure SSL (no cert verification) * project_{name|id}: name or ID of project """ return ksclient.Client(username=self.conf.os_username, password=self.conf.os_password, tenant_id=self.conf.os_project_id, tenant_name=self.conf.os_project_name, auth_url=self.conf.os_auth_url, insecure=self.conf.insecure) def _get_endpoint(self, client): """Get an endpoint using the provided keystone client.""" return client.service_catalog.url_for( service_type=self.conf.service_type or 'metering', endpoint_type=self.conf.endpoint_type or 'publicURL') def authenticate(self, api_version, request): """Get an authtenticated client, based on the credentials in the keyword args. :param api_version: the API version to use ('1' or '2') :param kwargs: keyword args containing credentials, either: * os_auth_token: pre-existing token to re-use * ceilometer_url: ceilometer API endpoint or: * os_username: name of user * os_password: user's password * os_auth_url: endpoint to authenticate against * insecure: allow insecure SSL (no cert verification) * os_project_{name|id}: name or ID of project """ if self.conf.os_auth_token and self.conf.marconi_url: token = self.conf.os_auth_token endpoint = self.conf.ceilometer_url elif (self.conf.os_username and self.conf.os_password and self.conf.os_auth_url and (self.conf.os_project_id or self.conf.os_project_name)): ks_kwargs = { 'username': self.conf.os_username, 'password': self.conf.os_password, 'tenant_id': self.conf.os_project_id, 'tenant_name': self.conf.os_project_name, 'auth_url': self.conf.os_auth_url, 'service_type': self.conf.os_service_type, 'endpoint_type': self.conf.os_endpoint_type, 'insecure': self.conf.insecure, } _ksclient = self._get_ksclient(**ks_kwargs) token = ((lambda: self.conf.os_auth_token) if self.conf.os_auth_token else (lambda: _ksclient.auth_token)) endpoint = self.conf.ceilometer_url or \ self._get_endpoint(_ksclient, **ks_kwargs) cli_kwargs = { 'token': token, 'insecure': self.conf.insecure, 'timeout': self.conf.timeout, 'ca_file': self.conf.ca_file, 'cert_file': self.conf.cert_file, 'key_file': self.conf.key_file, } # NOTE(flaper87): If this method # patches the request, do we really # need to return endpoint and cli_kwargs? return endpoint, cli_kwargs

commit_message:
Added test to check list/show extensions-neutron

Added a test script 'test_extensions.py' to api/networks to verify
if list/show of extensions is successful in neutron. Also added
supporting methods 'list_extensions' and 'show_extension_details' in
network client for XML and JSON interfaces.

Implements blueprint: quantum-test-l2-abstraction

Change-Id: Ie939a3e1302060489b579baf2cd3f7023efbeb7d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/30/45030/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # vim: tabstop=4 shiftwidth=4 softtabstop=4 # Copyright 2013 OpenStack, LLC # All Rights Reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from tempest.api.network import base from tempest.test import attr class ExtensionsTestJSON(base.BaseNetworkTest): _interface = 'json' """ Tests the following operations in the Quantum API using the REST client for Quantum: List all available extensions v2.0 of the Quantum API is assumed. It is also assumed that the following options are defined in the [network] section of etc/tempest.conf: """ @classmethod def setUpClass(cls): super(ExtensionsTestJSON, cls).setUpClass() @attr(type='gate') def test_list_show_extensions(self): # List available extensions for the tenant expected_alias = ['security-group', 'l3_agent_scheduler', 'ext-gw-mode', 'binding', 'quotas', 'agent', 'dhcp_agent_scheduler', 'provider', 'router', 'extraroute'] actual_alias = list() resp, extensions = self.client.list_extensions() self.assertEqual('200', resp['status']) list_extensions = extensions['extensions'] self.assertEqual(len(expected_alias), len(list_extensions)) for e in list_extensions: self.assertIn(e['alias'], expected_alias) # Show and verify the details of the available extensions for ext in list_extensions: ext_name = ext['name'] ext_alias = ext['alias'] resp, ext_details = self.client.show_extension_details(ext_alias) self.assertEqual('200', resp['status']) ext_details = ext_details['extension'] self.assertIsNotNone(ext_details) self.assertIn('updated', ext_details.keys()) self.assertIn('name', ext_details.keys()) self.assertIn('description', ext_details.keys()) self.assertIn('namespace', ext_details.keys()) self.assertIn('links', ext_details.keys()) self.assertIn('alias', ext_details.keys()) self.assertEqual(ext_details['name'], ext_name) self.assertEqual(ext_details['alias'], ext_alias) self.assertEqual(ext_details, ext) class ExtensionsTestXML(ExtensionsTestJSON): _interface = 'xml'

commit_message:
Add "public access to object storage accounts" to the cloud admin guide

Closes-Bug: #1224562

Change-Id: Ib9c526c93831003059067fda3c6295d0a7af3c9b
author: diane fleming
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/15/48115/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines:
GET'> HEAD'> PUT'> POST'> DELETE'> '> '> ]>
Public Access to Object Storage Accounts Use one of the following methods to give users access to an Object Storage account for a set period of time.
Temporary URL Use a temporary URL to enable users to access objects in an Object Storage account for a set amount of time. Your account does not have to be CDN-enabled to enable temporary public access through a temporary URL. For example, you might want your web site to provide a link that enables users to download a large file from your Object Storage account but the account has no public access. The web site can generate a URL that provides &GET; access for a limited time to the resource. When the user clicks on the link for this temporary URL on the web browser, the browser downloads the object directly from your Object Storage account, obviating the need for the web site to act as a proxy for the request. If the user were to share the link with friends or accidentally post it on a forum, the direct access is limited to the expiration time set when the web site created the link. When you create a temporary URL, &OBJSTOR; validates a &GET;- or &PUT;-accessible URL, which is time-limited. The temporary URL is the same as temporary URL Secret, and is set by using the temporary URL metadata key described in the following section. The temporary URL is the actual URL. To create a temporary URL for your account Set the account metadata key Export the API version and your tenant ID to the following environment variables: $ export api_version="<api_version> $ export account="<tenant_id>" On your &OBJSTOR; account, set the X-Account-Meta-Temp-URL-Key header to a key that only you know. The key is used to generate and authenticate the temporary URLs. There are no restrictions on its value. Set account metadata key for public access POST /$api_version/$account HTTP/1.1 Host: storage.swiftdrive.com X-Auth-Token: <your auth token> X-Account-Meta-Temp-Url-Key: <your key> A 2nn response indicates success. After you set the X-Account-Meta-Temp-URL-Key key, do not change it if you want others to continue to access your account through the temporary URL. If you change this key, the temporary URL stops working within 60 seconds, which is the cache time for a key. Generate an HMAC-SHA1 (RFC 2104) signature Generate an HMAC-SHA1 (RFC 2104) signature by using the HTTP method to define the method of access — &GET; or &PUT;, the path to the object, and the expiry in UNIX epoch notation. For example, the following code generates the signature for a &GET; request for 60 seconds on the /v1/AUTH_account/container/object object: Code to generate a signature for a temporary URL import hmac from hashlib import sha1 from time import time method = 'GET' expires = int(time() + 60) path = '/v1/AUTH_account/container/object' key = 'mykey' hmac_body = '%s %s %s' % (method, expires, path) sig = hmac.new(key, hmac_body, sha1).hexdigest() Be certain to use the full path, from the /v1/ onward.
Configuration options for filter:Temporary URL in proxy-server.conf file
Option Default Description
incoming_allow_headers
incoming_remove_headers x-timestamp
outgoing_allow_headers x-object-meta-public-*
outgoing_remove_headers x-object-meta-*
Give users access to the temporary URL Give users access to the full temporary URL to the object. For example, if sig equals da39a3ee5e6b4b0d3255bfef95601890afd80709 and expires equals 1323479485, the web site can provide a link to the following temporary URL: https://swift-cluster.example.com/v1/AUTH_account/container/object? temp_url_sig=da39a3ee5e6b4b0d3255bfef95601890afd80709& temp_url_expires=1323479485 If you do not provide users with the exact temporary URL, they receive 401 (Unauthorized) status errors. &HEAD; queries are allowed if &GET; or &PUT; are allowed. To override temporary URL file names Temporary URLs support the filename query parameter. Use this parameter to override the Content-Disposition header and define to which file name the browser should save the file. The following example shows a temporary URL without the file name override: Temporary URL without file name override https://cf-cluster.example.com/v1/AUTH_account/container/object?temp_url_sig=da39a3ee5e6b4b0d3255bfef95601890afd80709&temp_url_expires=1323479485 The following example appends &filename=bob.txt to the temporary URL, which instructs the browser to save the file as bob.txt: Temporary URL with file name override https://cf-cluster.example.com/v1/AUTH_account/container/object?temp_url_sig=da39a3ee5e6b4b0d3255bfef95601890afd80709&temp_url_expires=1323479485&filename=bob.txt
FormPost FormPost enables users to upload objects to your &OBJSTOR; account through a web form. FormPost translates a browser form request into a object &PUT; in &OBJSTOR;. After you enable FormPost on your account, you can create a form in your web site by using the following guidelines. In &OBJSTOR;, the object file size limit is 5 GB. If your users try to upload an object larger than 5 GB, a file size error occurs. To use FormPost to give users access to your account Set the account metadata key Export the API version and your tenant ID to the following environment variables: $ export api_version="<api_version> $ export account="<tenant_id>" On your &OBJSTOR; account, set the X-Account-Meta-Temp-URL-Key header to a key that only you know. The key is used to generate and authenticate the temporary URLs. There are no restrictions on its value. Set account metadata key for public access POST /$api_version/$account HTTP/1.1 Host: storage.swiftdrive.com X-Auth-Token: <your auth token> X-Account-Meta-Temp-Url-Key: <your key> A 2nn response indicates success. After you set the X-Account-Meta-Temp-URL-Key key, do not change it if you want others to continue to access your account through the temporary URL. If you change this key, the temporary URL stops working within 60 seconds, which is the cache time for a key. Create the form To enable users to communicate between your web site and your &OBJSTOR; account, create a form by using the following format in your web site: Layout of web form <form action="<CF-url>" method="POST" enctype="multipart/form-data"> <input type="hidden" name="redirect" value="<redirect-url>" /> <input type="hidden" name="max_file_size" value="<bytes>" /> <input type="hidden" name="max_file_count" value="<count>" /> <input type="hidden" name="expires" value="<unix-timestamp>" /> <input type="hidden" name="signature" value="<hmac>" /> <input type="file" name="file1" /><br /> <input type="submit" /> </form> Set the following parameters in the web form: form action="<CF-url>" Required. The &OBJSTOR; URL (CF-url) to the destination where files are to be uploaded. For instance: https://storage.clouddrive.com/v1/CF_xer7_34/container. The <CF-url> prefix is appended to the front of the name of each uploaded object. Your users upload directly to root of the container. You can also assign a specific prefix to each user to separate uploads, as follows: https://storage.clouddrive.com/v1/CF_xer7_34/container/user_prefix. method="POST" Required. Must be POST. enctype="multipart/form-data" Required. Must be multipart/form-data. name="redirect" value="<redirect-url>" Optional. The URL of the web page that displays after the form completes processing. Status and message query parameters are added to the URL. Status parameters define the HTTP status code for the upload (2nn indicates success). Message query parameters define text the provides further information if an error occurs, such as max_file_size exceeded. Although redirect is optional for the form, it must be present in the HMAC body. name="max_file_size" value="<bytes>" Required. Indicates the largest single file upload allowed, in bytes. This value must not exceed 5 GB. name="max_file_count" value="<count>" Required. The maximum number of files that can be uploaded with the form. name="expires" value="<unix-timestamp>" Required. A UNIX timestamp that defines the expiry. Time must be in UNIX epoch format. expires in the web form must match expires in the HMAC. name="signature" value="<hmac>" Required. The HMAC-SHA1 signature of the form. Code to generate a signature for a form post import hmac from hashlib import sha1 from time import time path = '/v1/account/container/object_prefix' redirect = 'https://myserver.com/some-page' max_file_size = 104857600 max_file_count = 10 expires = int(time() + 600) key = 'mykey' hmac_body = '%s %s %s %s %s' % (path, redirect, max_file_size, max_file_count, expires) signature = hmac.new(key, hmac_body, sha1).hexdigest()Be certain to use the full path, from the /v1/ onward. In the example, key is the value of the X-Account-Meta-Temp-URL-Key header set for the account. The max_file_count used to generate the signature must match the one in the web form. type="file" name="file1" Required. Defines the form file field. At least one entry is required to enable your users to select and upload a file, but you can include additional fields for multiple files. The number of entries should not, however, exceed the max_file_count value. Each type="file" field must have a different name. The type="file" fields must be at the end of the form code for &OBJSTOR; to process the uploads properly.

commit_message:
Incorrect error code impacted by debug level

Now there are something wrong with the WSME json code,
as a result, the HTTP return code will be wrong if the
Ceilometer debug level is set as False, which is impacting
almost all the exceptions defined in wsme.exc. But it
works fine with wsme.exc.ClientSideError, so using it
before the issue is fixed by WSME.

Fixes bug 1218760

Change-Id: I842aad841bdd21c0c51f0ee0c1fc8b671fc7c85f

commit_message:
make git show not display a diff

if the top commit includes actual content, this was being displayed
in the devstack log, which was just confusing. --quiet suppresses
this.

Change-Id: Id52604d3b2b9a1372746120cb5d8d741c35576b7

Fix xml response content for share list/show

limited data for xml version. make_share method in
shares.py updated to avoid data limiting during xml
serialization.

commit_message:
Adds explanatory text to warn admins when creating aggreates

to avoid confusing users booting in different availabilty zones.

Change-Id: I55550794c399c25f344a82bea7ea7661ad025228
Closes-bug: 1222665
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/25/48125/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: <para>Create a new aggregate named <replaceable><name></replaceable> in availability zone <replaceable><availability-zone></replaceable>. Returns the ID of the newly created aggregate. Hosts can be made available to multiple availability zones, but administrators should be careful when adding the host to a different host aggregate within the same availability zone and pay attention when using the aggregate-set-metadata and aggregate-update commands to avoid user confusion when they boot instances in different availability zones.</para>
deleted_lines: <para>Create a new aggregate named <replaceable><name></replaceable> in availability zone <replaceable><availability-zone></replaceable>. Returns the ID of the newly created aggregate.</para>

commit_message:
api ec2token: Clear failure when no auth_uri specified

Currently if the CFN API is misconfigured, such that no auth_uri
is set in the config, we silently fail because we don't detect that
auth_uri==None in the code.  Instead catch this situation and assert
that the service is misconfigured via a 500 response.

Change-Id: I47a385aa6a34fe3133de00cf2b18fec6a4f6645a
Partial-Bug: #1229674
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/67/48067/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def _authorize(self, req, auth_uri=None): if not auth_uri: logger.error("Ec2Token authorization failed, no auth_uri " "specified in config file") raise exception.HeatInternalFailureError("Service misconfigured")

subject: Improve the CM shell client alarm visualisation
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-09-24 10:15:40.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/python-ceilometerclient/commit/0972caa8b6291835194e04dff8685cc862a4784b', 'message': "Improve the CM shell client alarm visualisation

This change aim to get a better alarm representation in shell.

In alarm-list:
* it add a short sentence to describe the alarm rule
* it remove project_id/user_id because it always show the same id for
  all alarm for end-user

In alarm-show, it show alarm rule attributes as alarm properties instead
of a unparsable json in the rule property.

example of short sentence for column 'Alarm condition':
* combinated states (AND) of 8babd6a2-c457-42d0-9eb5-cdfb3cb50203,
  d0e11a94-8f59-48a9-8f6d-b0d68aaac8d0
* cpu_util ge 50.0 during 1 x 60s

Change-Id: If4df2dc08f9f4cb7796fd98308c7d62e311d1138
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2013-09-24 10:16:30.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/python-ceilometerclient/commit/8d58c79832249f376f6d1992be63c6aceb30a1d7', 'message': "Improve the CM shell client alarm visualisation

This change aim to get a better alarm representation in shell.

In alarm-list:

commit_message:
Improve the CM shell client alarm visualisation

This change aim to get a better alarm representation in shell.

In alarm-list:
* it add a short sentence to describe the alarm rule
* it remove project_id/user_id because it always show the same id for
  all alarm for end-user

In alarm-show, it show alarm rule attributes as alarm properties instead
of a unparsable json in the rule property.

example of short sentence for column 'Alarm condition':
* combinated states (AND) of 8babd6a2-c457-42d0-9eb5-cdfb3cb50203,
  d0e11a94-8f59-48a9-8f6d-b0d68aaac8d0
* cpu_util >= 50.0 during 1 x 60s

Change-Id: If4df2dc08f9f4cb7796fd98308c7d62e311d1138
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-ceilometerclient refs/changes/05/48005/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def alarm_rule_formatter(alarm): if alarm.type == 'threshold': return ('%(meter_name)s %(comparison_operator)s ' '%(threshold)s during %(evaluation_periods)s x %(period)ss' % { 'meter_name': alarm.rule['meter_name'], 'threshold': alarm.rule['threshold'], 'evaluation_periods': alarm.rule['evaluation_periods'], 'period': alarm.rule['period'], 'comparison_operator': alarm.rule['comparison_operator'] }) elif alarm.type == 'combination': return ('combinated states (%(operator)s) of %(alarms)s' % { 'operator': alarm.rule['operator'].upper(), 'alarms': ", ".join(alarm.rule['alarm_ids'])}) else: # just dump all return "\n".join(["%s: %s" % (f, v) for f, v in alarm.rule.iteritems()]) field_labels = ['Alarm ID', 'Name', 'State', 'Enabled', 'Continuous', 'Alarm condition'] fields = ['alarm_id', 'name', 'state', 'enabled', 'repeat_actions', 'rule'] formatters={'rule': alarm_rule_formatter}, sortby=0) fields = ['name', 'description', 'type', data.update(alarm.rule)
deleted_lines: field_labels = ['Name', 'Description', 'State', 'Enabled', 'Continuous', 'Alarm ID', 'User ID', 'Project ID'] fields = ['name', 'description', 'state', 'enabled', 'repeat_actions', 'alarm_id', 'user_id', 'project_id'] sortby=0) fields = ['name', 'description', 'type', 'rule',

commit_message:
Comparing device name values instead of their reference

Although end users specified device name as `vda' but since `is' in
python is used to compare reference, bootable volume is not
detected. We should use `==' to compare values instead.

Fixes bug #1229610

Change-Id: I7f127dc489706482f6bb245372bfd8079b91c40f

commit_message:
Replace first_public_address/first_private_address

OS::Nova::Server attributes first_public_address and first_private_address
will not work with neutron, which allows any network name to be assigned
not just 'public' and 'private'.

This change replaces these attributes with a 'first_address'
attribute which uses the same nova_utils.server_to_ipaddress method
that AWS::EC2::Instance uses to populate all of its IP address
attributes.

This needs to be fixed before the Havana release to avoid these
broken attributes needing to be supported.

Change-Id: I0b4dc009d665e4d7b4cbc32d484a2efc6068320a
Closes-Bug: #1228929

subject: HOT str_replace to use string.replace, not string.Template
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-09-23 01:56:39.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/heat/commit/2de387b7079452055ec42a266bce6f2748b2aff2', 'message': 'HOT str_replace to use string.replace, not string.Template

str_replace uses python templates, whereas Fn::Replace uses python
string.replace.

During the original review for Fn::Replace, python templates were
decided against because $ would often need double-escaping in shell scripts.
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/31736/

Having different behaviours between Fn::Replace and str_replace will
add complication for users migrating existing templates to HOT.

Another advantage of using straight string replacement is seen when
the template generates a executable script. In this case it is generally
possible to write a template that can also be executed directly in a
dev/test environment. This would often not be possible if the template
format required placeholders to be prefixed with a $.

Whatever behaviour exists when Havana is release will have to be
supported indefinitely so now is the time to decide if this is going
to be fixed.

Closes-Bug: #1228640
Change-Id: I72879b374a3c61dfe0e4004251ab709d914f2e25
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2013-09-23 21:01:30.000000000', 'files': ['heat/engine/hot.py', 'doc/source/template_guide/hot_spec.rst', 'heat/tests/test_hot.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/heat/commit/f424d6f6c3fec5a534c7850551ad62b4f055b606', 'message': 'HOT str_replace to use string.replace, not string.Template

commit_message:
HOT str_replace to use string.replace, not string.Template

str_replace uses python templates, whereas Fn::Replace uses python
string.replace.

During the original review for Fn::Replace, python templates were
decided against because $ would often need double-escaping in shell scripts.
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/31736/

Having different behaviours between Fn::Replace and str_replace will
add complication for users migrating existing templates to HOT.

Another advantage of using straight string replacement is seen when
the template generates a executable script. In this case it is generally
possible to write a template that can also be executed directly in a
dev/test environment. This would often not be possible if the template
format required placeholders to be prefixed with a $.

Whatever behaviour exists when Havana is release will have to be
supported indefinitely so now is the time to decide if this is going
to be fixed.

Closes-Bug: #1228640
Change-Id: I72879b374a3c61dfe0e4004251ab709d914f2e25

commit_message:
LVM volume_clear: error on unexpected inputs

Currently if a user configures
volume_clear='non_existent_volume_clearer' in cinder.conf,
the LVM driver will silently delete a volume and not wipe it.

Instead, the delete operation should fail, leaving the volume
in the 'error_deleting' state.

Also fail if the volume reference does not contain either a
'size' or 'volume_size' field.

Closes-Bug: #1225194
Change-Id: I78fec32d7d5aeaa8e2deeac43066ca5e2e26d9ca
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/72/46572/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: msg = (_("Error: unrecognized volume_clear option: %s") % self.configuration.volume_clear) raise exception.CinderException(msg)
deleted_lines: LOG.error(_("Error unrecognized volume_clear option: %s"), self.configuration.volume_clear) return

commit_message:
Fix editing of nameless images

We can't assume image.name is a valid attribute as Glance
doesn't send it for images that don't have a name.

This is a targeted fix to handle two cases where we access the name.
Where the name is not available, this shows the ID instead.

In the future we may want to look at wrapping images in our own class
so we can clean up data as it is returned from the API.

Change-Id: Ida50ce74efafff287a0189dc90aa529e80bd5961
Closes-bug: 1223921
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/69/48169/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Fix excessive volume_get requests in snaps table

The volume snapshots table has a column that shows the associated volume
name and links to its volume detail page. This calls volume_get twice
for each snapshot, so loading the Images & Snapshots page takes forever
if you have a decent number of snapshots.

This commit instead gets the volume list at the same time as the
volume snapshot list, and stores the volume as an attribute on
the snapshot so it can be easily retrieved later.

Closes-bug: 1218259
Change-Id: I004e50aae51a6ed7549da41967bc42babfa6cb45

commit_message:
Allow Django unknown language in LANGUAGES settings

Language preference form expects all languages in LANGUAGES in
openstack_dashboard/settings.py. This leads to an error when
adding a language not listed in django/conf/locale to LANGUAGES list.

This commit allows such language to LANGUAGES in the settings file.

Closes-Bug: #1229026

Change-Id: I37d7f4b089b0299942f25084f741a557467b3be7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/83/47783/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Don't send unuseful rpc alarm notification

If the alarm have no actions for the new state we don't need to send a
message through the rpc for notification, just log a debug message
when it occur.

Fixes bug 1224416

Change-Id: I9aeb01e936dbacfbabb06e8b408d5ee04a93cb34

commit_message:
Added XML serialization for access actions

Resources related to share access management hasn't xml
serrialisation so it returns incorrect response for xml
requests. XML temptates constructors added to

commit_message:
Colorize Neutron log output and refactor log setup code

Bug 1214616

This patch adds colors to on-screen Neutron log output in the same way nova,
cinder, and heat engine do.
To this aim, colorized logging configuration has been moved to ./functions.
The reason for this refactoring is that these instruction are the same or
very similar for each project, with the only exception of the target
configuration file.

Change-Id: Idf0d1b842bb9ab046c9ef826de1dfc55b3f1df9d

commit_message:
Check policy implementation for shares api.

At this moment shares api don't check policy for
most actions. Special check policy decorator added
for necessary methods at api.py, to solve this problem.

Change-Id: I6a11fbf5d5162ec49670103a98872d3e00e2d996
Fixes: Bug#1223375
Fixes: Bug#1223379

The $or clause was removed from one of the queries in
ClaimController.create() because it is no longer necessary,
and makes the query slower than it would otherwise be.

Mongo will just use the _id_ index now, which should be fine

commit_message:
fix(mongodb): Remove $or clause used to claim messages

The $or clause was removed from one of the queries in
ClaimController.create() because it is no longer necessary,
and makes the query slower than it would otherwise be.

Mongo will just use the _id_ index now, which should be fine
since scanning a small set of messages by c.e is fast.

Change-Id: Ifcb918ef66d072a10690ad49406f4a787e84becd
Implements: blueprint bp/api-perf-tuning
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/zaqar refs/changes/90/47590/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # NOTE(kgriffs): Set the claim field for # the active message batch, while also # filtering out any messages that happened # to get claimed just now by one or more # parallel requests. # # Filtering by just 'c.e' works because # new messages have that field initialized # to the current time when the message is # posted. There is no need to check whether # 'c' exists or 'c.id' is None. 'c.e': {'$lte': now}},
deleted_lines: # Set claim field for messages in ids '$or': [ {'c.id': None}, { 'c.id': {'$ne': None}, 'c.e': {'$lte': now} } ]},

subject: Do not set error_attach and error_detach states
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-09-22 09:40:25.000000000', 'files': ['cinder/volume/manager.py', 'cinder/tests/test_volume.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/823b7d5492397be4ee1d5893f797f83b9e2d31ff', 'message': "Do not set error_attach and error_detach states

Failing to attach or detach a volume should not affect its status (for
example, due to passing a bad parameter). Exceptions are still raised,
and the volume's state is left unchanged. This should be sufficient to
detect a failed attach/detach, without affecting future operations on
the volume due to changed status.

Fixes: bug 1223189

Change-Id: I415dec19125ae29be4ce56522733ed18c5b09382
"}]
commit_message:
Do not set error_attach and error_detach states

Failing to attach or detach a volume should not affect its status (for
example, due to passing a bad parameter). Exceptions are still raised,
and the volume's state is left unchanged. This should be sufficient to
detect a failed attach/detach, without affecting future operations on
the volume due to changed status.

Fixes: bug 1223189

Change-Id: I415dec19125ae29be4ce56522733ed18c5b09382
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/35/47735/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Add volume name arguments

This patch adds volume name arguments to the following subcommands:
 * snapshot-create
 * backup-create
 * backup-restore
 * transfer-create

Fixes bug #1220590

Change-Id: Ib0ff6e62d45abb14fa8c7313511ef6f72befe0d5

commit_message:
Stop nested stack updates exceeding resource limit

This is the final way for a user to exceed the max_resources_per_stack
configuration value.

Fixes bug #1215100

commit_message:
Remove version from setup_requires

setup_requires cannot effect an upgrade, but a version being listed can
block things from operating happily. Remove the version pin from
setup_requires. Also, the setup_hooks are no longer needed.

Change-Id: Idda7d67a21c9245ca8c17973e847629bd3b4e3f2

commit_message:
Add locking to test_list_hosts_with_zone

test_list_hosts_with_zone() makes 2 list_hosts calls and expects that
the hosts' availability zone will remain constant between the calls.
However when running in parallel there is no guarantee of this, and
the aggregates tests will change the compute host's availability
zone. This commit adds the 'availability_zone' to the test to ensure
it doesn't run at the same time as the tests which will change the
host's availability zone.

Fixes bug 1228225

Change-Id: I14773e38b5cc35679b16940ad230c7c81aeaad9c

commit_message:
Fix processutils.execute errors on windows

Added a check for existence of geteuid.

This fix is related to oslo-incubator commit:
d6a963e911b8456c06dceb5ee3cc88a70c08bf82

Fixes bug #1209410

Replace GA db saves with RPC cals to taskmanager (part 1)

This is a part of refactoring intended to reduce dependency
of trove.guestagent on server-side related packages

commit_message:
Prevent modal forms from closing

Forbit form closing by clicking on the backdrop.
This will prevent data lost without any other actions.
It still possible to close from on the "Esc" button.

Fixes bug#1062065

Change-Id: I6be7f76a242687bedbf9185ba627a3ffbe556ab3

commit_message:
Adds support for admin to create flavors through mgmt API

Extending the management API to allow for an admin to
create flavors categorized on service type in trove.

Change-Id: Iaa0c930c9d211726a8a5ffb0cca7faf03695b65d
Implements: blueprint service-type-filter-on-flavors
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/trove refs/changes/67/44767/9 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright 2013 Hewlett-Packard Development Company, L.P. # All Rights Reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. # from mockito import mock, when, verify, unstub, any from testtools import TestCase from testtools.matchers import Equals, Is, Not from novaclient.v1_1 import Client from novaclient.v1_1.flavors import Flavor from trove.common.context import TroveContext from trove.common import remote from trove.extensions.mgmt.flavors.models import FlavorManage class MockMgmtFlavorTest(TestCase): def setUp(self): super(MockMgmtFlavorTest, self).setUp() self._context = TroveContext() self._client = mock(Client) self._flavor_x = mock(Flavor) self._flavor_x.name = 'flavor_101' self._flavor_x.id = '101' self._flavor_x.ram = '1024' self._flavor_x.disk = '20' self._flavor_x.vcpu = '2' self._flavor_models = FlavorManage(self._context) when(remote).create_admin_nova_client(self._context).thenReturn( self._client) def tearDown(self): super(MockMgmtFlavorTest, self).tearDown() unstub() def test_create(self): self.assertIsNotNone(self._flavor_models) when(self._flavor_models).create('flavor_101', '1024', '2', '20', '101', '0', '0', '1.0', 'True', 'mysql').thenReturn(self._flavor_x) flavor_y = self._flavor_models.create('flavor_101', '1024', '2', '20', '101', '0', '0', '1.0', 'True', 'mysql') self.assertIsNotNone(flavor_y) self.assertEqual(self._flavor_x.name, flavor_y.name, 'Flavor Name is not correct') self.assertEqual(self._flavor_x.id, flavor_y.id, 'Flavor ID is not correct') self.assertEqual(self._flavor_x.ram, flavor_y.ram, 'RAM is not correct') self.assertEqual(self._flavor_x.disk, flavor_y.disk, 'Disk is not correct') self.assertEqual(self._flavor_x.vcpu, flavor_y.vcpu, 'CPU is not correct')

commit_message:
Security group rules validation allows duplicate rules

This commit fixes the issue where neutron would allow duplicate security
groups rules if protocol numbers and names are interchanged.

Change-Id: Ideece7aa6b48cd2fbf37e7b704a95e56366458ea
Fixes: Bug 1215181
